liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Transport Minister Catherine King 's explanation into the decision to block Qatar Airways' additional flight request has left more questions, as the federal government remains under pressure with a Senate inquiry set to probe the issue. Critics of the decision say it's not in the national interest and will cost the economy $1 billion. Professor Rico Merkert, the chair in transport from the University of Sydney Business School, spoke to The Business host Alicia Barry about the ongoing saga that's enfulged Canberra. You can watch their full chat below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ðŸ“º Blocking Qatar Airways' extra flights could cost the economy $1 billion, expert says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Chevron spokesperson has just provided a statement in response to Chevron workers walking off the job this afternoon as their industrial dispute continues. "We have been advised by the unions that protected industrial action will not take place at our facilities until 1.00pm AWST Friday 8 September. "We will continue to work through the bargaining process as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company. "We will also continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron responds to strike action to be taken by workers

children.content: A Chevron spokesperson has just provided a statement in response to Chevron workers walking off the job this afternoon as their industrial dispute continues.
"We have been advised by the unions that protected industrial action will not take place at our facilities
until 1.00pm AWST
Friday 8 September.
"We will
continue to work through the bargaining process
as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company.
"We will also continue to take steps to
maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption
at our facilities."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator's deputy chair, Sarah Court, spoke to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan about ASIC's legal action against AustralianSuper over its duplicate account failures. She told The World Today the fact the conduct occurred for 10 years was concerning. "What we're concerned [with] here, we've got the largest superfund in the country," she said. "This conduct went for a period of about 10 years, 90,000 members affected and $69 million is being remediated. "These obligations have been in place since 2013. And yes, we at ASIC have been calling on the superannuation industry to make sure that they do have the right processes and systems in place to meet these obligations." But Ms Court declined to say how big a penalty ASIC was seeking over the issue, but expects it to be substantial. "It's an early stage ... I think, suffice to say, there is the potential for very significant penalties to be imposed in relation to this conduct," she said. "But that is down the track and we will wait and see where we get to in the court proceedings."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC says 'very significant penalties' could be imposed on AustralianSuper

children.content: The corporate regulator's deputy chair,
Sarah Court
, spoke to
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan
about ASIC's legal action against
AustralianSuper
over its duplicate account failures.
She told
The World Today
the fact the conduct occurred for 10 years was concerning.
"What we're concerned [with] here, we've got the largest superfund in the country," she said.
"This
conduct went for a period of about 10 years, 90,000 members affected and $69 million is being remediated

"These obligations have been in place since 2013. And yes, we at ASIC have been calling on the superannuation industry to make sure that they do have the right processes and systems in place to meet these obligations."
But Ms Court declined to say how big a penalty ASIC was seeking over the issue, but expects it to be substantial.
"It's an early stage ... I think, suffice to say,
there is the potential for very significant penalties to be imposed
in relation to this conduct," she said.
"But that is down the track and
we will wait and see
where we get to in the court proceedings."
